metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of fractional vegetation cover and biomass observed in the middle of Heihe River Basin (2013)
metadata.description:
The dataset includes the fractional vegetation cover data generated from the stations of crop land, wetland, Gebi desert and desert steppe in Yingke Oasis and biomass data generated from the stations of crop land (corn) and wetland. The observations lasted for a vegetation growth cycle from 19 May, 2012 to 15 September, 2012.
1.	Fractional vegetation cover observation
1.1	Observation time
1.1.1	Station of the crop land: The observations lasted from 20 May, 2012 to 15 September, 2012, and in five-day periods for each observation before 31 July and in ten-day periods for each observation after 31 July.
The observation time for the station of crop land (corn) are 2013-5-20, 2013-5-25, 2013-5-30, 2013-6-5, 2013-6-10, 2013-6-16, 2013-6-22, 2013-6-27, 2013-7-2, 2013-7-7, 2013-7-12, 2013-7-17, 2013-7-27, 2013-8-3, 2013-8-13, 2013-8-25, 2013-9-5 and 2013-9-15.
1.1.2	The other four stations: The observations lasted from 20 May, 2012 to 15 September, 2012 and in ten-day periods for each observation.
The observation time for the crop land are 2013-5-20, 2013-6-5, 2013-6-16, 2013-6-27, 2013-7-7, 2013-7-17, 2013-7-27, 2013-8-3, 2013-8-13, 2013-8-25, 2013-9-5 and 2013-9-15.
1.2	method
1.2.1 Instruments and measurement method
Digital photography measurement is implemented to measure the FVC. Plot positions, photographic method and data processing method are dedicatedly designed. In field measurements, a long stick with the camera mounted on one end is beneficial to conveniently measure various species of vegetation, enabling a larger area to be photographed with a smaller field of view. The stick can be used to change the camera height; a ﬁxed-focus camera can be placed at the end of the instrument platform at the front end of the support bar, and the camera can be operated by remote control.
1.2.2 Design of the samples
Three and two plots with the area of 10×10 m^2 were measured for the station of the crop land and wetland, respectively. One plot with the area of 10×10 m^2 was measured for the other three stations. Shoot 9 times along two perpendicularly crossed rectangular-belt transects. The picture generated of each time is used to calculate a FVC value. “True FVC” of the plot is then acquired as the average of these 9 FVC values.
1.2.3 Photographic method
The photographic method used depends on the species of vegetation and planting pattern. A long stick with the camera mounted on one end is used for the stations of crop land and wetland. For the station of the crop land, rows of more than two cycles should be included in the ﬁeld of view (<30), and the side length of the image should be parallel to the row. If there are no more than two complete cycles, then information regarding row spacing and plant spacing are required. The FVC of the entire cycle, that is, the FVC of the quadrat, can be obtained from the number of rows included in the field of view. For other three stations, the photos of FVC were obtained by directly photographing for the lower heights of the vegetation.
1.2.4 Method for calculating the FVC
The FVC calculation was implemented by the Beijing Normal University. The detail method can be found in the reference below. Many methods are available to extract the FVC from digital images, and the degree of automation and the precision of identification are important factors that affect the efficiency of field measurements. This method, which is proposed by the authors, has the advantages of a simple algorithm, a high degree of automation and high precision, as well as ease of operation (see the reference).
2. Biomass observation
2.1. Observation time
2.1.1 Station of the crop land: The observations lasted from 20 May 2012 to 15 September 2012, and in five-day periods for each observation before 31 July and in ten-day periods for each observation after 31 July.
The observation time for the crop land are 2013-5-25, 2013-5-30, 2013-6-5, 2013-6-10, 2013-6-16, 2013-6-22, 2013-6-27, 2013-7-2, 2013-7-7, 2013-7-12, 2013-7-17, 2013-7-27, 2013-8-3, 2013-8-13, 2013-8-25, 2013-9-5 and 2013-9-15.
2.1.2 The station of wetland: The observations lasted from 20 May 2012 to 15 September 2012, and in ten-day periods for each observation.
The observation time for the crop land are 2013-6-5, 2013-6-16, 2013-6-27, 2013-7-7, 2013-7-17, 2013-7-27, 2013-8-3, 2013-8-13, 2013-8-25, 2013-9-5 and 2013-9-15.
2.2. Method
Station of the crop land: Three plots were selected and three strains of corn for each observation were random selected for each plot to measure the fresh weight (the aboveground biomass and underground biomass) and dry weight. Per unit biomass can be obtained according to the planting structure.
Station of the wetland: Two plots of reed with the area of 0.5 m × 0.5 m were random selected for each observation. The reed of the two plots was cut to measure the fresh weight (the aboveground biomass) and dry weight.
2.3. Instruments
Balance (accuracy 0.01 g); drying oven
3. Data storage
All observation data were stored in excel. Other data including plant spacing, row spacing, seeding time, irrigation time, the time of cutting male parent and the harvest time of the corn for the station of cropland were also stored in the excel.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how digital cameras are utilized for vegetation coverage data collection in eco-hydrological experiments?
Example.Answer: In the 黑河生态水文遥感试验, digital cameras are used to capture images for vegetation coverage measurement. The cameras are placed on a simple support rod, pointing vertically downwards, and operated remotely. This method allows for targeted measurement across different vegetation types by adjusting the camera height. Coverage is calculated by classifying images into green vegetation and non-green background using an automated method that converts RGB to Lab color space.

Example.Question: What is an example of a method used to measure biomass in different vegetation types during an ecological experiment?
Example.Answer: In the 黑河生态水文遥感试验, biomass is measured using different methods for corn and reeds. For corn, representative plants are selected, and their fresh and dry weights are measured to calculate biomass per unit area. For reeds, samples are cut from designated plots, and their fresh and dry weights are measured. Weighing is done using a balance with precision to 0.01g, and drying is performed at 85°C to obtain dry weight.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how multiscale datasets are constructed to study eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert environment?
Example.Answer: In the HiWATER experiment, a multiscale dataset is created using a combination of flux observation matrices with eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, alongside an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index measurements. Airborne remote sensing with LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and other instruments complements ground measurements, forming a comprehensive dataset for studying eco-hydrological processes.

Definition.Question: What does 'coverage observation' entail in the context of eco-hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of eco-hydrological data collection, 'coverage observation' involves using digital cameras to capture images for measuring vegetation coverage. The method includes placing the camera on an instrument platform attached to a support pole, ensuring vertical downward shooting, and remotely controlling the camera to collect data. This setup allows for targeted measurement depending on vegetation type, with a designed sample plot for photo capturing along diagonals to calculate average coverage.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'biomass observation' in assessing ecosystem dynamics?
Definition.Answer: Biomass observation is significant in assessing ecosystem dynamics as it involves measuring the fresh and dry weight of vegetation, such as corn and reeds, to calculate biomass per unit area. This process includes selecting representative plants or plots, weighing them, and using specific measurements like plant spacing to determine biomass. It provides crucial data on vegetation growth and productivity, which are key indicators of ecosystem health and dynamics.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for vegetation coverage using digital cameras compare to multiscale eco-hydrological observations in terms of instrumentation and scale?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for vegetation coverage involve using digital cameras placed on instrument platforms to capture images for coverage calculation, with a focus on small-scale, targeted vegetation measurements. In contrast, multiscale eco-hydrological observations employ a variety of instruments, including eddy covariance towers and remote sensing tools, to capture processes at multiple scales, from individual plant dynamics to landscape-level interactions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in observation frequency and data granularity between the vegetation coverage and biomass data collection and the intensive observation periods of eco-hydrological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The vegetation coverage and biomass data collection is conducted at fixed intervals, with observations every 5 to 10 days, providing detailed temporal data for specific vegetation sites. In contrast, intensive observation periods for eco-hydrological processes involve continuous data collection across multiple instruments, capturing a broad range of temporal and spatial scales, potentially offering a more comprehensive dataset but with less frequent, individual site-specific detail.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection methods can be inferred or developed to enhance the accuracy of vegetation cover assessment in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: The field utilizes digital camera photography combined with remote control and automated classification algorithms to accurately measure vegetation cover. This suggests that methods focusing on digital imaging and automated data processing can enhance accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How does the multiscale observation approach address the challenges of capturing eco-hydrological processes in diverse environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The multiscale observation approach involves using a variety of instruments across different nested scales, which captures eco-hydrological processes effectively. This method integrates eddy covariance towers, meteorological stations, and remote sensing tools to gather comprehensive data in diverse environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the frequency and timing of vegetation coverage observations in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The frequency and timing of vegetation coverage observations are influenced by the growth cycles of the vegetation being studied. For example, during the growth period from May to September, observations were made every 5 days until the end of July and every 10 days afterward. These intervals are determined by the need to capture significant changes in vegetation coverage over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is digital photography used as a data collection method for vegetation coverage in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Digital photography is used because it allows for targeted measurement of vegetation coverage by providing a visual and quantifiable method to capture data. The technique involves placing a digital camera on a platform to take vertically downward photos, which are then analyzed to determine vegetation coverage. This method is simple, automated, and provides high accuracy in distinguishing vegetation from the background.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using digital cameras placed on adjustable platforms for measuring vegetation coverage?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using digital cameras on adjustable platforms allows for targeted measurement by adjusting the height based on vegetation type. This method ensures a vertical downward shot, enhancing precision and enabling automation in calculating vegetation coverage through color space transformation and clustering techniques.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the adoption of a multiscale observation system affect the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The adoption of a multiscale observation system provides comprehensive data that captures eco-hydrological processes across different scales. This approach supports the investigation of interactions within oasis-desert systems and enhances the quality of data through hierarchical instrumentation and synchronization of various sensing technologies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of integrating ground measurements with hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing in environmental research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating ground measurements with hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing results in a robust dataset that combines detailed local observations with broader spatial data. This integration improves the accuracy and reliability of eco-hydrological studies by providing multiscale insights and facilitating a better understanding of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to observe biomass and coverage data over a complete growth cycle for vegetation types like corn and reed?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Observing biomass and coverage over a full growth cycle is crucial to understand the dynamics and development of vegetation, which can provide insights into ecosystem productivity and health over time.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are utilized to measure vegetation coverage using digital photography in eco-hydrological studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Digital photography is used to measure vegetation coverage by placing a digital camera on an instrument platform at the end of a simple support rod, ensuring vertical downward shooting. The camera is remotely controlled to capture data. The setup allows for changing the shooting height to target different types of vegetation. The coverage calculation involves converting RGB color space to Lab space to differentiate green vegetation from non-green backgrounds, using histogram clustering of the green component to calculate coverage.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is biomass data collected for different vegetation types, and what instruments are utilized in this process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Biomass data for corn and reed is collected by selecting sample plots and measuring fresh and dry weights. For corn, three representative plants are selected per plot, and both aboveground and underground biomass is measured using a balance with 0.01g precision. For reeds, two 0.5m x 0.5m plots are harvested at ground level, and fresh and dry weights are measured. A balance and an oven for drying at 85°C are used in the process.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in ensuring data quality and consistency when collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality and consistency are ensured through careful calibration of sensors, structured data collection methods, and thorough data processing. Instrumentation is arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multiscale processes, with consistent observations across various landscapes. Data is recorded initially in notebooks and then organized into Excel spreadsheets, including metadata like planting structure and management details, ensuring a comprehensive and organized dataset.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the automatic classification of vegetation coverage from digital photographs in ecological water experiments?
Enablement.Answer: The automatic classification of vegetation coverage is enabled by converting RGB color space to the Lab color space, where green vegetation can be more easily distinguished. This method utilizes clustering of the greenness component 'a' in the Lab space to separate green vegetation from non-green backgrounds.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methods ensure the collection of reliable biomass data in ecological remote sensing experiments?
Enablement.Answer: Reliable biomass data collection is ensured by selecting representative samples from designated plots, weighing fresh and dry biomass, and using precise instruments like a balance with 0.01g accuracy and an oven for drying. These samples are then used to calculate biomass per unit area based on planting distances.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of digital cameras for cover data collection in eco-hydrological studies be preferred over traditional measurement methods?
Expectation.Answer: The digital camera method allows for targeted measurements by changing the camera's shooting height and offers a simple, easy-to-implement algorithm for automatic classification with high precision. This method maximizes the advantages of digital cameras in capturing vegetation cover data.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise from the lack of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes, and how does this impact expected research outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The lack of multiscale observations hinders progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. This challenge affects expected research outcomes by limiting the ability to capture interactions across different landscape scales, which is crucial for comprehensive eco-hydrological modeling.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to implement both sparse networks and intensive observations in eco-hydrological experiments, and what outcomes are anticipated from such an approach?
Expectation.Answer: Implementing sparse networks alongside intensive observations allows for capturing interactions across different landscape scales, such as oasis-desert interactions. This approach is expected to provide a more comprehensive understanding of multiscale eco-hydrological processes, facilitating better data integration and analysis.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the challenges of limited multiscale observations impact the quality of eco-hydrological data collected in heterogeneous landscapes, such as oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: The limited availability of multiscale observations can significantly impact the quality of eco-hydrological data collected in heterogeneous landscapes by hindering the comprehensive understanding of complex processes. This can lead to gaps in capturing interactions across different spatial and temporal scales, ultimately affecting the reliability and applicability of the data for broader research and management purposes.

Judgmental.Question: What potential improvements can be made to the existing methods of biomass observation to enhance data accuracy and reliability in similar ecological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential improvements to biomass observation methods could include the integration of advanced remote sensing technologies, such as LiDAR or multispectral imaging, to supplement ground-based measurements. Additionally, refining sampling techniques and incorporating more frequent and diverse data collection points could enhance the accuracy and reliability of biomass data in ecological studies.

Assertion.Question: I can't quite grasp how the use of digital cameras for measuring vegetation coverage ensures accuracy and automation in the data collection process.
Assertion.Answer: The use of digital cameras involves taking vertical downward photos using a camera placed on a support platform, allowing for remote control of the camera for data measurement. The technique uses an automatic classification method, transforming RGB color space into Lab space, which helps distinguish green vegetation and calculate coverage. This method is noted for its simplicity, ease of implementation, high degree of automation, and precision in computing vegetation coverage.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how researchers manage to collect accurate biomass data of different vegetation types over an entire growing season.
Assertion.Answer: For biomass data collection, researchers select sample plots and measure fresh and dry weights of vegetation samples. For corn, they choose representative plants and measure fresh and dry biomass. For reeds, they use sample plots, harvest the vegetation, and weigh the biomass. The observations are recorded meticulously, and calculations are made based on planting distances to determine biomass per unit area.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the data collection methods used for observing vegetation coverage and biomass in the context of eco-hydrological experiments.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for observing vegetation coverage and biomass involve using digital photography with a camera mounted on a simple support rod, capturing vertical downward images. The observation framework allows for adjusting the camera height to target different vegetation types. Coverage calculation utilizes an automatic classification method based on RGB to Lab color space transformation, enabling separation of green vegetation from the background. Biomass observation involves measuring fresh and dry weight of selected vegetation samples and calculating biomass per unit area.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with collecting multiscale eco-hydrological observation data and propose potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological observation data is the poor availability of multiscale observations. To address this, HiWATER implemented instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including superstations and EC towers, as well as multiple remote sensing missions using LiDAR and spectrometers to capture diverse eco-hydrological processes. Solutions could involve enhancing the spatial and temporal resolution of data collection and expanding the sensor network to cover more varied landscapes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and describe potential sources or repositories where relevant multiscale eco-hydrological datasets can be accessed.
Request/Directive.Answer: Relevant multiscale eco-hydrological datasets can be accessed from repositories such as figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre. HiWATER's data, which includes flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and remote sensing data, are carefully quality controlled and made freely available through these platforms.
